archetype_tagline: I answer to a higher law
archetype_description: Nullifiers who decide based on personal principles rather than legal instructions. Will follow conscience over evidence. Can cause hung juries. Unpredictable and difficult to move once position is formed.

core_characteristics.key_dynamic: Personal moral/philosophical framework overrides legal instructions

subtypes.description: Decides based on personal sense of justice/morality regardless of law
subtypes.typical_lean: Often plaintiff in cases involving perceived injustice

subtypes.description: Rejects government authority including legal instructions
subtypes.typical_lean: Often defense in cases involving regulations

subtypes.description: Views case through lens of systemic racism

detection_indicators: Expresses strong personal moral or philosophical framework
Questions legitimacy of legal system or instructions
States that conscience/God/principles come before law
Has history of civil disobedience or activism
Expresses views that 'the system is broken'
Extreme positions on either end of political spectrum
States they would have trouble following instructions they disagree with
voir_dire_detection_questions: If the judge instructs you to apply a rule of law you personally disagree with, could you follow that instruction?
Do you believe there are situations where a juror should follow their conscience instead of the law?
Have you ever heard of jury nullification? What do you think about it?
Is there any law or legal principle you feel so strongly about that you couldn't set it aside?

personas.tagline: The law isn't always just. I've seen unjust laws before.
life_experiences: Grew up during Jim Crow, participated in civil rights movement
Has seen unjust laws and defied them on moral grounds
40 years as pastor, strong moral framework
Explicitly endorsed jury nullification in sermons
Believes jurors should follow conscience, not just law
Taught that law isn't always right

nullification_philosophy.core_belief: There is a higher moral law than what is written in legal books
nullification_philosophy.historical_reference: Civil rights movement showed that unjust laws must be opposed
nullification_philosophy.application: Will prioritize justice over legal instructions if they conflict
nullification_philosophy.likely_direction: Pro-plaintiff in cases involving perceived injustice against individuals

characteristic_phrases: The law isn't always just
There's a higher law than what's written in books
We have to follow our conscience
I've seen unjust laws before
Justice requires more than following instructions
I answer to God before I answer to any judge

instruction_question.question: If the judge instructs you to apply a rule you disagree with, could you follow that instruction?
instruction_question.response: I would listen respectfully to the judge. But ultimately, I answer to God and my conscience. I've seen unjust laws before. I'd have to do what I believed was right.

nullification_question.question: Have you ever heard of jury nullification?
nullification_question.response: Yes, I have. I believe it's one of the most important powers citizens have. It's how we keep the legal system accountable to justice.

fairness_question.question: Can you be fair to both sides?
fairness_question.response: I believe in fairness. But fairness and following instructions aren't always the same thing. Sometimes being fair means standing up for what's right even when the system says otherwise.

influence_tactics: Refuses to be moved by legal arguments
likely_statements: I don't care what the instructions say—this is about justice
I've seen what happens when people just follow rules without thinking
My conscience won't let me rule that way
This is about right and wrong, not technicalities

plaintiff_vs_corporation.reasoning: Will see as individual vs powerful institution, invoke justice

civil_rights_adjacent.reasoning: Strong identification with civil rights framing

regulatory_compliance_defense.reasoning: May view regulatory compliance as insufficient if moral wrong occurred

cause_challenge_approach.strategy: His own statements reveal nullification intent. Use his words.
script: You mentioned you've endorsed jury nullification. Does that mean you might not follow the judge's instructions?
You said you answer to God before any judge. Does that mean you might decide this case based on your religious beliefs rather than the law?
If the law required a result your conscience disagreed with, would you follow your conscience instead?
cause_challenge_approach.expected_outcome: High likelihood of successful cause challenge based on stated views

strategy_guidance.warning: Statements likely support cause challenge. If retained, high risk of hung jury if he opposes majority.

personas.tagline: The government has no business telling me how to live or how to judge.
life_experiences: Third-generation Montana rancher
Deeply distrusts government and large institutions
Believes in personal freedom and personal consequences
Has fought with government agencies over land use, regulations
Libertarian political philosophy
May refuse to apply laws he views as government overreach

nullification_philosophy.core_belief: Government has no right to tell citizens how to run their lives or businesses
nullification_philosophy.constitutional_reference: Strict constructionist; if not in Constitution, government can't do it
nullification_philosophy.application: May refuse to enforce regulations he sees as illegitimate government overreach
nullification_philosophy.likely_direction: Defense in cases involving government regulations; variable otherwise

characteristic_phrases: The government has no right to tell people how to run their business
Where does it say in the Constitution...
This is just lawyers making money
People should be free to make their own choices and live with consequences
Another government regulation that doesn't make sense
I don't trust the government to tell me what's right

regulation_question.question: This case involves whether the defendant violated federal safety regulations. Do you have any feelings about government regulations?
regulation_question.response: I think there are way too many regulations. The government has no business telling people how to run their businesses. Half these regulations are written by bureaucrats who've never done a day of real work.

instruction_question.question: Could you follow the judge's instructions even if you disagreed with the underlying law?
instruction_question.response: Depends on the instruction. If the judge tells me to enforce some regulation I think is unconstitutional, I'd have a hard time with that. A man's got to follow his principles.

lawsuit_question.question: What do you think about lawsuits generally?
lawsuit_question.response: Too many of them. People should handle their own problems, not run to courts. And lawyers take too much. The whole system is rigged.

influence_tactics: Questions legitimacy of regulations at issue
Appeals to freedom and personal responsibility
May refuse to engage with legal framework
likely_statements: Why should we enforce this regulation anyway?
The government shouldn't be involved in this
Both sides are wrong—people should handle this themselves
I'm not going to be the government's tool

regulatory_violation.reasoning: May refuse to enforce regulations he views as illegitimate

individual_vs_individual.reasoning: May expect plaintiff to have handled it themselves

corporate_negligence.reasoning: Dislikes both corporations and lawsuits; unpredictable

cause_challenge_approach.strategy: Focus on refusal to follow legal instructions regarding regulations
script: You mentioned you'd have a hard time enforcing regulations you disagree with. This case involves federal safety regulations. Can you apply them?
If the judge instructs you that violation of a regulation can establish negligence, could you follow that instruction?
It sounds like you have strong views about government overreach. Would those views prevent you from being fair in a case involving regulations?

strategy_guidance.warning: Unpredictable. May nullify in either direction depending on how case is framed. High risk of hung jury.

personas.tagline: The system has never been fair to people who look like me.
life_experiences: Degree in sociology with focus on systemic racism
10 years as community organizer in Oakland
Active in Black Lives Matter movement
Views legal system as fundamentally racist
Believes in using any available tool to achieve racial justice
Family members have had negative experiences with legal system

nullification_philosophy.core_belief: The legal system has always been a tool of oppression against Black people
nullification_philosophy.historical_reference: From slavery to mass incarceration, the law has never been just
nullification_philosophy.application: Will prioritize racial justice over legal technicalities
nullification_philosophy.likely_direction: Pro-plaintiff against institutions; may nullify to protect defendants of color

characteristic_phrases: The system has never been fair to people who look like me
We need to talk about the racial dynamics here
This is about more than just this case
Justice means something different when you've been oppressed
I'm not going to participate in an unjust system
We have a chance to do something right for once

fairness_question.question: Can you be fair to both sides regardless of their race?
fairness_question.response: That question assumes the system is fair to begin with. It's not. I'll try to do what's right, but I'm not going to pretend history doesn't exist.

corporation_question.question: Could you be fair to a corporate defendant?
corporation_question.response: Corporations have been exploiting communities of color forever. I can listen to the evidence, but I know how these institutions operate.

instruction_question.question: Could you follow the judge's instructions on the law?
instruction_question.response: If the instructions are just, yes. If they perpetuate injustice, I'd have to think about that.

influence_tactics: Frames issues in terms of systemic justice
May introduce arguments about broader social context
likely_statements: We need to consider what justice really means here
This is bigger than just one case
The law doesn't operate the same way for everyone
I'm not going to help perpetuate an unjust system

individual_vs_individual.reasoning: Less ideologically driven when no institutional defendant

cause_challenge_approach.strategy: Focus on statements suggesting inability to follow instructions
script: You mentioned you might not follow instructions you see as unjust. How would you decide what's unjust?
Could you set aside your views about systemic racism and just evaluate the evidence in this case?
If the law required a result you felt was unfair, could you follow the law?

strategy_guidance.notes: May be challengeable for cause depending on statements. Defense will likely use peremptory strike.

personas.tagline: Lawsuits are destroying this country. I won't be part of it.
life_experiences: Owned manufacturing business for 35 years
Sued multiple times, considers all lawsuits against him frivolous
Active in tort reform advocacy
Believes trial lawyers are parasites
Views plaintiff litigation as fundamentally illegitimate
May refuse to find for any plaintiff on principle

nullification_philosophy.core_belief: Lawsuits are destroying American business and society
nullification_philosophy.moral_framework: Plaintiffs and their lawyers are gaming the system for money
nullification_philosophy.application: Will not help 'lottery justice' succeed regardless of evidence
nullification_philosophy.likely_direction: Pro-defense in all cases; may nullify to prevent any plaintiff verdict

characteristic_phrases: Lawsuits are destroying this country
Another money grab by trial lawyers
I won't be part of this lawsuit lottery
People used to handle problems themselves
Trial lawyers are parasites
No matter what the evidence shows, I can't support this kind of lawsuit

lawsuit_views_question.question: What are your views on personal injury lawsuits?
lawsuit_views_question.response: I think they're out of control. Trial lawyers are destroying businesses, driving up costs for everyone. It's legalized extortion. I've been sued multiple times for nothing.

fairness_question.question: Could you be fair to a plaintiff bringing a personal injury lawsuit?
fairness_question.response: I don't know. Honestly, I look at these cases and I just see money grabs. I've been on the other side of it. I know how the game works.

instruction_question.question: If the evidence showed the defendant was negligent, could you find for the plaintiff?
instruction_question.response: I'd have a hard time. I just don't believe in this whole system. Even if someone was technically negligent, these lawsuits do more harm than good.

influence_tactics: Dismisses all plaintiff evidence as exaggerated
Refuses to engage with liability analysis
May simply announce he won't vote for plaintiff regardless
likely_statements: I'm not going to help these trial lawyers
This is just another lottery ticket lawsuit
I don't care what the evidence shows—these lawsuits are wrong
You can't make me vote for the plaintiff

all_plaintiff_cases.reasoning: Rejects legitimacy of plaintiff litigation entirely

cause_challenge_approach.strategy: His own statements are clear grounds for cause challenge
script: You said you'd have a hard time finding for a plaintiff even if the evidence showed negligence. Is that accurate?
You mentioned you 'don't believe in this whole system.' Does that mean you've already decided against the plaintiff?
You said you won't help 'trial lawyers' regardless of evidence. Can you give the plaintiff a fair hearing?
cause_challenge_approach.expected_outcome: Clear cause challenge. His statements admit inability to be fair.

strategy_guidance.warning: Should be removed for cause. His statements explicitly admit he cannot follow the law or be fair to plaintiffs. If somehow seated, will hang jury to prevent plaintiff verdict.

strategic_summary.detection_priority: HIGH - Mavericks can cause hung juries and unpredictable outcomes
key_voir_dire_questions: If the judge instructs you to apply a rule of law you disagree with, could you follow that instruction?
Do you believe there are situations where a juror should follow their conscience instead of the law?
Is there anything about lawsuits in general that would make it difficult for you to be fair to either side?
cause_challenge_triggers: Statement that conscience/God/principles come before legal instructions
Admission of inability to be fair to one side regardless of evidence
History of civil disobedience with stated intent to continue

if_seated_risks.deliberation_disruption: May refuse to engage with legal framework
if_seated_risks.unpredictability: Outcome may not correlate with evidence strength
